entry.title: S/4+EWM - API call for planned Handling Units (HUs)
entry.content:
Hi everyone, I'm currently working with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (2023) with SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) and I'm trying to automate a delivery from production process using APIs only.

My goal is to create an Inbound Delivery and the corresponding planned Handlings Units. I'm following the documentation provided here: Operations for Handling Unit API

I've been trying for days to create a planned HU via API but it doesn't work. The only thing that worked were stock HUs üòê

Is there any way to create planned Handling Units for a given Product through an API? If yes, could someone please share an examples payload?

I‚Äôd really appreciate any tips or suggestions. Thanks a lot!
Bart

entry.title: Plan for migration of interfaces to SAP Cloud Integration(Int. Suite)
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

We are in to aumotive industry,, This is regarding our ongoing plan to replace all the existing PO/PI instances with the shared SAP Cloud Integration(Int. Suite). As you know, we currently have Team A, Team B, Team C, , each using their own SAP PO/PI system, SAP backends, and individual integration teams. Say for example team A ; team B ;; team C ;;   Also each team has its distinct partner system or common partner system &  common plants between each two teams.  I have the following questions in terms of better architecture, implementation, design, stability, future proof, and operations etc.,

(i) Would it be beneficial for each team to migrate their ICOs to their own Pipeline concept iFlows.

(ii) Should we migrate interfaces system by system (or) plant by plant in a phased manner.

(iii) Standardization and Consistency, Operational Efficiency, Resource Management and Faster Migration (Long-Term), better integration patterns and reducing the complexity etc.

Regards,

Ramu.

entry.title: How to use a Subaccount Destination in the Sender Adapter in BTP - Integration Suite
entry.content: I would like to know how I can reference a destination in my iFlow in SAP Integration Suite. I know I could use externalized parameters, but it is not possible to reference destinations.

entry.title: SAP CPI - IBMMQ adapter setup MQRC_JSSE_ERROR.
entry.content:
I need help understanding why IBM MQ adapter in CPI does not connect to MQ server due to SSL/TLS problems with MQRC_JSSE_ERROR.

Using WebSphere MQ 9.3.0.5 on Windows.

Steps to setup:
1. Create self-signed cert on MQ Server, 

runmqakm -keydb -create -db srt04684.kdb -pw <secret> -type cms -stash

runmqakm -cert -create -db srt04684.kdb  -pw <secret> -label ibmwebspheremqqm1010t -dn "CN=srt04684,C=SE"  -size 2048  -x509version 3 -expire 730 -sig_alg SHA256WithRSA

runmqakm -cert -extract -db srt04684.kdb -pw <secret> -label ibmwebspheremqqm1010t -target srt04684.arm -format ascii

2. Config QMGR, including copying certificate files to /ssl directory and updating QMGR SSL key repository (excluding .kbd), setting the password and also setting the certificate label to "ibmwebspheremqqm1010t"

3. Create SVRCONN channel SAPISCLIENT.CH, set CipherSpec to "TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA256" (have tried multiple others). No SSL Authentication.

4. Restart QMGR

5.Config cloud connector, with virtual name matching the servername "srt04684", port 1414. Verified connectivity

6. Added public Cert that was exported in MQ server to SAP CPI keystore. Named it "srt04684".

7. Created iFlow with the following parameters in IBMMQ Sender subscribe:

Hostname: srt04684
Port: 1414
Proxy type: Om Premise
SSL Cipher Suite: TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA256
QueueManagerName: QM1010T
Channel name: SAPISCLIENT.CH

Error on CPI:

[CONTENT][CONTENT_DEPLOY][RuntimeError] : {"message":"POLL_FAILED","childMessageInstances":[{"message":"EXCEPTION","parameters":["org.apache.camel.CamelException: Error message: An error occurred while starting or stopping JMS Connection. Reason: JMSCMQ0001: IBM MQ call failed with compcode '2' ('MQCC_FAILED') reason '2397' ('MQRC_JSSE_ERROR').."]}],"parameters":["IBMMQ://JMS_SUBSCRIBE?authentication=none&ccsid=1208&channelName=SAPISCLIENT.CH&cipherSuitCloudConn=TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_128_CBC_SHA256&connectionProtocol=tcpip&delay=300000&entit ... [truncated

I have also tried to create a certificate with CN=qm1010t but not succeeded with that.
I have tried multiple SSL Cipher values including *ANY, *TLS12ORHIGHER,  and others...

Any help is appreciated.

Regards
Andreas

entry.title: CPI Integration Flow: Weather Alert using Open-Meteo API (cities list loop + email notification)
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I am working on a scenario in which I want to build an automated iFlow in SAP Cloud Platform Integration (CPI) to send weather alerts. The requirements are as follows:

 

  • Read a list of cities (e.g., Nagpur, Mumbai, Delhi)

  • For each city:

     

    • Fetch latitude & longitude dynamically using the Open-Meteo Geocoding API

    • Then call the Open-Meteo Weather API using those coordinates

    • Read the current temperature value

    • Check for conditions:

      • If temperature > 35 ¬∞C ‚Üí ‚ÄúHigh Temperature Alert‚Äù

      • If temperature < 5 ¬∞C ‚Üí ‚ÄúLow Temperature Alert‚Äù

    • Send an email notification with the city name, temperature and the alert message

I have started designing the iFlow with a Timer, looping splitter, HTTP calls, Groovy scripts for extraction and condition logic, and an Email receiver adapter.

What I need help with:

  • Best practice for looping through a list of cities in CPI (should I use an array in a Content Modifier, external CSV, or OData?)

  • How to correctly map and extract the response from the Geocoding API (first result latitude/longitude) ‚Üí any sample Groovy script or mapping advice would be great

  • How to structure the error handling when an API returns no result or the city name is not found

  • Any suggestions for optimizing the iFlow for performance, especially if the list of cities grows to ~50+

I will also attach a screenshot of my current iFlow configuration (Timer, Splitter, content modifier, HTTP channel, etc.) to show where I am stuck.

If anyone is available and open to help or review the design with me, I would greatly appreciate it. Thank you in advance for your time and advice!

Regards,
Safar

entry.title: How To get compliant with iFlow Design Guidelines - Define Identifiers To Search In Message
entry.content:
Hello SAP experts,

I use the designguidelines when creating iFlows, but there is one point where I am unable to achieve compliance.

It concerns the following point in the Design Guidelines: Define Identifiers To Search In Message Processing Logs.

My current approach:

At the beginning of the iFlow, I have implemented a Groovy script that stores important values for identifying the customer in the CustomHeaderProperty.

Unfortunately, this does not seem to be enough to make me compliant with the Design Guidelines under ‚ÄòDefine Identifiers To Search In Message Processing Logs‚Äô.

Here is the Groovy script I used:

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;

def Message processData(Message message) {
    
	def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message);
	if(messageLog != null){

		def sEquiID = message.getHeaders().get("EquiID");		
		if(sSapAuthenticatedUserName!=null){
			messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty("EquiID", sEquiID);		
        }

		def sOrderID = message.getHeaders().get("OrderID");		
		if(sSapAuthenticatedUserName!=null){
			messageLog.addCustomHeaderProperty("OrderID", sOrderID);		
        }

	}
	return message;
}

 

Do you have any idea what else I need to do?

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: API Execution Failed When Trying to Use ‚ÄúTry Out‚Äù Feature in SAP Cloud Integration API on BTP Trial
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I recently ran into an issue while experimenting with SAP Cloud Integration on my SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) Trial Account, and I wanted to share my experience here in case anyone else has faced something similar‚Äîor if someone can point me in the right direction.

Scenario

As part of my learning journey in SAP Integration Suite, I created an Integration Flow (iFlow) in Cloud Integration (CPI) and successfully deployed it.

Then, I exposed the iFlow as an API through the API Management capability of BTP so that I could access it externally via a REST API call.

Everything went smoothly until I tried to test the API using the ‚ÄúTry Out‚Äù feature from SAP API Business Hub.

Steps Followed

  1. Logged in to my SAP BTP Trial account.

  2. Opened Integration Suite ‚Üí Cloud Integration.

  3. Created and deployed an iFlow that returns some sample data.

  4. Exposed the iFlow as an API Proxy using API Management ‚Üí Design ‚Üí API Proxies.

  5. Opened the Cloud Integration API package on SAP API Business Hub.

  6. Clicked ‚ÄúTry Out‚Äù to test one of the APIs (for example, /MessageProcessingLogs).

  7. Given the clientid and clientsecret from instance default_it-rt_integration-flow and also I tried with my BTP sign inuser id and password and it shows API execution failed. Please try again.

    Issue Facing

    When I clicked Execute, the system returned the following message:

    API execution failed. Please try again.

    No additional error details were displayed in the response window, and the API call did not reach my iFlow endpoint.

    Troubleshooting Attempted

    Here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve tried so far:

    • Verified that the iFlow is deployed and active.

    • Checked the runtime URL from the Monitor ‚Üí Manage Integration Content page.

    • Verified that my trial tenant is active and not in suspended state.

    • Checked API Business Hub ‚ÄúTry Out‚Äù feature for other packages ‚Äî same issue occurs, which might indicate an environment limitation.

      My Understanding So Far

      It seems that the ‚ÄúTry Out‚Äù feature on SAP API Business Hub might not support BTP Trial environments for certain APIs, especially those requiring authenticated connections to Cloud Integration runtime.

      In a productive BTP setup (non-trial), the ‚ÄúTry Out‚Äù function usually works fine when proper credentials and destinations are configured.

      Request for Help

      Has anyone successfully used the Cloud Integration API ‚ÄúTry Out‚Äù feature with a Trial account?
      If so, could you please share:

      • Any specific configuration or destination settings needed for trial accounts

      • Whether OAuth token-based authentication is mandatory

      • Or if this limitation is by design for BTP Trial users

        Conclusion

        I‚Äôm learning a lot about SAP Integration Suite and the API Management capabilities on BTP.
        Even though I‚Äôve hit this roadblock, it‚Äôs been a great opportunity to understand how authentication and API exposure work behind the scenes in the SAP ecosystem.

        Would love to hear from the community if anyone has faced and resolved this issue! üôå

entry.title: Is It Time to Bring AI Workflows Into SAP Automation?
entry.content:
I‚Äôve been experimenting lately with ways to bring more autonomy into SAP workflows. Most automation setups still rely on rules or triggers, they do what they‚Äôre told, but they don‚Äôt adapt when data or processes change.

What‚Äôs been fascinating is how much potential there is in combining SAP process automation with AI-driven decision logic. Imagine workflows that can detect anomalies in purchase orders, reroute approvals based on context, or sync data intelligently with non-SAP systems without manual rules.

The challenge I keep running into is how to design these ‚ÄúAI-aware‚Äù workflows without adding too much complexity or breaking governance.

So I‚Äôm curious has anyone here tried integrating AI-driven workflows with SAP? Are you doing it through BTP, Integration Suite, or experimenting with other tools or APIs? What‚Äôs been working for you (and what hasn‚Äôt)?

Subhashini Rawat

entry.title: Why iFlow Replicate Sales Order and Sales Quote from SAP S4HANA only allows iDocs
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I am currently working on a standard integration between SAP S/4HANA On-Premise and SAP Sales Cloud Version 2 for the replication of Sales Orders ‚Äì from S/4 to Sales Cloud v2.

I have come across something that seems completely inconsistent, and I cannot explain it:

1. In DRFIMG, the only outbound implementation for Sales Orders is 114_1 (Webservice)

In DRFIMG ‚Üí Define Outbound Implementations, the object SalesOrder only offers the Webservice outbound implementation 114_1.
There is no IDoc outbound option available.

2. The SAP standard iFlow for Sales Cloud v2, however, expects an IDoc structure

In the SAP Integration Suite package ‚ÄúSAP Sales Cloud Version 2 Integration for Sales Processes with SAP S/4HANA‚Äù, the sender adapter for the iFlow ‚ÄúReplicate Sales Order and Sales Quote from SAP S/4HANA‚Äù must be configured as IDoc.
The iFlow clearly expects an IDoc XML payload.

If you send SOAP/Webservice messages instead, errors occur such as:

  • HTTP 401

  • unsupported xstream in SRT_MONI

Which makes sense, because the iFlow internally seems to process IDoc payloads only, not SOAP.

My question to the community:

How does this fit together?

  • Is this an intentional design?

  • Why is the iFlow still using IDoc structures here?

  • If DRFIMG does not provide an IDoc outbound implementation, how is this integration supposed to work?

  • What are the recommended options or best practices?

  • Any guidance or tips from someone who has implemented this scenario successfully would be greatly appreciated.

entry.title: What is the simplest way you have seen teams manage integration sprawl in SAP landscapes?
entry.content:
As more cloud apps get connected to SAP, the number of small workflows and automations grows quickly. I am trying to understand how teams maintain visibility and control when dozens of integrations start triggering across systems.

Would love to hear if anyone has a clean way of documenting and monitoring these flows without relying too much on custom scripts or manual maps.

entry.title: How to access failed messages from AEM Dead Message queue (DMQ) in Cloud Integration?
entry.content:
I have a scenario where i am connecting iFlow in CI to AEM via the AdvancedEventMesh adapter and as per the current design, i need to retry a failed message a few times (intermittent connectivity issue) before moving the message to a Dead message queue (DMQ) in AEM. My question here is 

  1.  How do i access the message from DMQ later and move it to the original queue for my iFlow to reprocess the message towards the target system?
  2. Should I create a separate queue for DMQ in the Broker manager?
  3. How do i make sure the retry process doesn't go on a loop if the message i retry from the DMQ doesn't get delivered to the target?

Thanks.

entry.title: Integration Suite Cloud Connector Connectivity Test fails
entry.content:
I'm trying to set up Cloud Connector to my BTP and Integration Suite so I can access SMB shares on an internal Windows 11 server.

Everything I can see the status of, looks like everything is working except it seems Integration Suite isn't talking to BTP,  maybe.

Here are screenshots of everything I have running.

Cloud Connector on Windows Machine

This windows machine has confirmed access to the SMB file share I want to get files from.

Tested in PowerShell and basic authentication user name and password are verified working.

‚ÄÉ

Status of that cloud connector

‚ÄÉStatus of connection in BTP

I set up a "Destination" in BTP as a test as well just to see and that checks out.

But, now In integration suite if I try and use this in a SMB Adapter in an iFlow I get errors (some details obscured, my company is very sensitive)

All of the parameters are 100% correct (as long as this is what is supposed to go there).

Address is the virtual address I have set up.

Location ID is the Location ID is have set up in Cloud Connector on the Windows Machine

Share is the name of the Share Drive I'm trying to access via SMB on the Windows Machine

Credentials Name is set up and deployed and verified as correct username and password that can access the SMB share at the destination.

"org.apache.camel.CamelException: <Exception><Message>Error in Session connect: On-Premise connection failed for bXX-XXX:445. Ensure cloud connector is configured correctly for location id : us-XXX-XXX and host is exposed correctly in your cloud connector. SMB uses TCP as protocol. Error : SOCKS5 command failed with status: NETWORK_UNREACHABLE</Message></Exception>"

Also, in Integration Suite, if I go to "Monitor->Manage Security->Connectivity Tests->Cloud Connector"

and put in my location ID the only feedback I get is "Could not connect to Cloud Connector" error.

Not sure how to proceed to try and get this working.

entry.content:

Automating student inquiries

Enhancing academic workflow management

Integrating with LMS/SIS platforms

Predictive analytics for student success

Improving administrative efficiency on campus

What are the recommended SAP services, integration patterns, or best practices for deploying AI agents securely and at scale in a higher education environment?

entry.title: Cloud Integration Certificate with Key Size upper than 2048
entry.content:
Hi All,

it should be possibile to obtain directly from SAP, using an SR request, a new sap_cloudintegrationcertificate on IS Tenant with:

  • Key Size: 3072
  • Signature Algorithm: sha256ECDSA
  • Issude by: DigiCert

I know tha we have already the 2048 one, but for security constraint we need a new version with a 3072 Key Size.

 

Thanks

Regards

entry.title: CPI message mapping error for attribute xml:lang
entry.content:
Dear experts,

I'm trying to simulate passing value to an attribute named "xml:lang" from a test xsd. I was able to successfully import the test xsd by creating a local download of https://www.w3.org/2001/xml.xsd and uploading it as part of the message mapping references with the name 2001.xsd.  

I've passed constant values to all the elements and attributes but simulation results in Test error, if i set the attribute "xml:lang" to optional I'm able to simulate the message mapping but the attribute is missing. Could you advise how to handle this or if there's no other way other than thru XSLT or Groovy script?

 

<xsd:schema xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"
    xmlns:xml="http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace"
    elementFormDefault="unqualified">

    <xsd:import namespace="http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace"
        schemaLocation="2001.xsd" />

    <xsd:element name="start">
        <xsd:complexType>
            <xsd:sequence>
                <xsd:element name="targetelement">
                    <xsd:complexType>
                        <xsd:simpleContent>
                            <xsd:extension base="xsd:string">
                                <xsd:attribute ref="xml:lang" use="required"/>
                            </xsd:extension>
                        </xsd:simpleContent>
                    </xsd:complexType>
                </xsd:element>
            </xsd:sequence>
        </xsd:complexType>
    </xsd:element>

</xsd:schema>

entry.title: BrSupply Suprimientos Corporativos Punchout Integration to SAP BTP CPI
entry.content:
Hello, I have the following scenario.

Our company developed a SAP FIORI UI5 application which runs on the cloud foundry environment. From this app, the user is lead to a punchout catalogue. The process is something like this :

1. Hit punchout button
2. A request is sent to an oData service exposed from S4H (on-premise)
3. oData calls CPI
4. CPI calls external provider which returns a url, this is url is the punchout catalogue site that is returned to the UI5 appication.
5. UI5 application uses this url an open a new browser tab.

And here is where the problem is happening


The url which is opened in the browser belongs to an external site (punchout catalogue), from there the user calls an API REST endpoint exposed in SAP BTP CPI, we already provide the credentials to the provider admin to authenticate to the BTP but they state they aren't able to send the credentials and for sure they aren't able to complete the purchase process from the punchout site. Have you guys ever worked on an integration like so, I mean , punchout catalogue to SAP BTP CPI? The API REST exposed by cpi internally calls an oData service, I was wondering if this integration isn't posible (punchout ---- cpi) , is it possible to expose the s4 hanna service to the provider (punchout- catalogue) without using CPI. S4H in this case is on-premise

 

Hope this is clear, if you have any questions let me know.

entry.title: Configuring OAuth 2.0 Authentication between SAP API Management and SAP Cloud Integration
entry.content:
Alright, let‚Äôs get started, buddy! üòÉ

Assuming API Management is active in your Integration Suite tenant, the first step is to set up the API Proxy.

Step 1: Create an API Proxy to Generate an Access Token 

 

Create an API Proxy using the URL type, and provide any dummy hostname since the target endpoint won‚Äôt actually be invoked.

 

After creating the API Proxy, set the Target Endpoint to ‚ÄúNone‚Äù in the Proxy Endpoint section, as shown in the screenshot below, and click on save.


Step 2 : Add a policy to generate the OAuth 2.0 Authentication.

In the Proxy Endpoint‚Äôs PreFlow, add the OAuth policy, ensuring it is applied on the incoming request stream.

OAuth 2.0 ‚Äì Used to generate the access token for the API call.

<OAuthV2 async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
	<ExternalAuthorization>false</ExternalAuthorization>
	<GrantType>request.queryparam.grant_type</GrantType>
	<Operation>GenerateAccessToken</Operation>
	<GenerateResponse enabled="true"/>
	<SupportedGrantTypes>
		<GrantType>client_credentials</GrantType>
	</SupportedGrantTypes>
</OAuthV2>

Step 3: Create a Product in the Engage section of Integration Suite

Add the API Proxy GenerateAccessToken to the Product APIM_Product

Step 4 : Create a subscription in the Developer Hub

Navigate to Developer Hub ‚Üí My Workspace ‚Üí Create New Subscription (e.g., APIM_Product).



You will get these two items from APIM_Product: The Application Key (your username) and the Application Secret (your password).

Step 5 : Now, let‚Äôs test the API Proxy for GenerateAccessToken

Test the API Proxy using Basic Authentication by supplying the Application Key as the username, the Application Secret as the password, and adding the grant_type as a query parameter. I‚Äôve also attached a screenshot showing the generated access token.

Step 6 : Create API Provider

To validate the setup, you must create an API Provider. Navigate to API Provider, click Create, and enter the following details:

  1. Type: Cloud Integration
  2. Host
  3. Port
  4. Client ID
  5. Client Secret
  6. Token URL*

Click Test Connection; you should receive an ‚ÄúOK‚Äù message with a 200 response code. I‚Äôve attached a screenshot for your reference.

Step 7 : Develop the Integration Flow to serve as the proxy and then deploy it.

I have created a simple Integration Flow that includes a Content Modifier with the body .I‚Äôve attached a screenshot for your reference.

Step 8 : create a proxy using API Provider

Select the provider, click Discover, choose the API, and then click Create


Your proxy will be created and then assign the API Proxy to the Product as shown in below screenshot.

Step 9: Now, let‚Äôs verify the access token
Apply the OAuthV2 policy to the Demo API Proxy.

OAuth 2.0 - To verify the OAuth Token generated.

<OAuthV2 async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
   <ExternalAuthorization>false</ExternalAuthorization>
   <Operation>VerifyAccessToken</Operation>
   <GenerateResponse enabled="true"/>
</OAuthV2>

Assign Message ‚Äì If you encounter the error {"fault":{"faultstring":"Unsupported Encoding \"br\"","detail":{"errorcode":"protocol.http.UnsupportedEncoding"}}}, it's because BR (Brotli) is a compression format typically used by backends for webpage loading, and it is not supported here. Using the Assign Message policy helps remove this unsupported encoding so the message can reach the target successfully


Assign Message 

<AssignMessage async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
	<Remove>
		<Headers>
			<Header name="Authorization"/>
		</Headers>
	</Remove>
	<IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>false</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>
	<AssignTo createNew="false" type="request">request</AssignTo>
</AssignMessage>

Click on save and deploy .

Step 9 : Testing Time
In Postman, select OAuth 2.0 as the authentication type, then:

  • Set the Access Token URL
  • Enter the Client ID
  • Enter the Client Secret
  • grant_type=client_credentials
  • Click Get New Access Token


From Cloud Integration

From API Management 

And we‚Äôre done! OAuth 2.0 Authentication is configured for SAP API Management in SAP Cloud Integration. You may now take a victory sip of coffee‚Äîyou earned it üòé

Reference

https://help.sap.com/docs/integration-suite/sap-integration-suite/oauth-v2-0 

https://docs.apigee.com/api-platform/security/oauth/oauth-20-client-credentials-grant-type
